åŸå§‹ä¿¡æ¯

Description:

elFinder before 2.1.48 contains a command injection caused by unsanitized input in the PHP connector, letting attackers execute arbitrary commands, exploit requires attacker to send crafted requests.

Severity: Critical
POC:
  • https://www.exploit-db.com/exploits/46481/
  • https://www.exploit-db.com/exploits/46539/
  • https://github.com/cved-sources/cve-2019-9194

KEV: True

Shodan Query: http.title:"elfinder"

Acceptance Criteria: The template must include a complete POC and should not rely solely on version-based detection. Contributors are required to provide debug data(-debug) along with the template to help the triage team with validation or can also share a vulnerable environment like docker file.

Rewards will only be given once the template is fully validated by the team. Templates that are incomplete or invalid will not be accepted. Avoid adding code templates for CVEs that can be achieved using HTTP, TCP, or JavaScript. Such templates are blocked by default and wonâ€™t produce results, so we prioritize creating templates with other protocols unless exceptions are made.

You can check the FAQ for the Nuclei Templates Community Rewards Program here.

æ¼æ´æè¿°ï¼š WordPress Celestial Auraä¸»é¢˜ï¼ˆç”±dkszoneå¼€å‘ï¼‰ç‰ˆæœ¬2.2åŠä»¥ä¸‹å­˜åœ¨ä¸€ä¸ªä¸å—é™åˆ¶çš„æ–‡ä»¶ä¸Šä¼ æ¼æ´ã€‚ä½æƒé™è®¤è¯ç”¨æˆ·å¯ä»¥é€šè¿‡ä¸»é¢˜çš„ç®¡ç†é¢æ¿ä¸Šä¼ ä»»æ„PHPæ–‡ä»¶ï¼Œå¯èƒ½å¯¼è‡´è¿œç¨‹ä»£ç æ‰§è¡Œï¼ˆRCEï¼‰ã€‚å—å½±å“çš„æ–‡ä»¶æ˜¯wp-admin/admin.php?page=CA-settingsï¼Œä»»ä½•è®¤è¯ç”¨æˆ·ï¼ˆè®¢é˜…è€…åŠä»¥ä¸Šï¼‰å‡å¯åˆ©ç”¨æ­¤æ¼æ´ï¼Œä¸”æ²¡æœ‰nonceã€æ–‡ä»¶ç±»å‹æˆ–æ‰©å±•åéªŒè¯ã€‚

äº§å“å‚å•†ï¼š dkszone

äº§å“åç§°ï¼š WordPress Celestial Aura Theme

å½±å“ç‰ˆæœ¬ï¼š <= 2.2

æ¥æºï¼š https://github.com/Nxploited/CVE-2025-26892

ç±»å‹ï¼š CVE-2025:github search

ä»“åº“æ–‡ä»¶

  • CVE-2025-26892.py
  • LICENSE
  • README.md

åŸå§‹ä¿¡æ¯

CVE-2025-26892 â€“ WordPress Celestial Aura Theme <= 2.2 Arbitrary File Upload (Authenticated)

ğŸ“„ Description

An Unrestricted File Upload vulnerability exists in the WordPress Celestial Aura theme (developed by dkszone) up to version 2.2.
A low-privileged authenticated user can upload arbitrary PHP files through the themeâ€™s admin panel, potentially leading to Remote Code Execution (RCE).

  • Affected theme: Celestial Aura
  • Affected versions: â‰¤ 2.2
  • Vulnerable file: wp-admin/admin.php?page=CA-settings
  • Exploitable by: Any authenticated user (subscriber and above)
  • No nonce, file type, or extension validation

ğŸ›¡ï¸ CVSS Score

Patchstack CNA Rating:

  • Base Score: 9.9 (CRITICAL)
  • Vector: CVSS:3.1/AV:N/AC:L/PR:L/UI:N/S:C/C:H/I:H/A:H

ğŸš€ Usage

The script logs in with the provided credentials, uploads a malicious PHP shell (nxploit.php) via the vulnerable theme settings, and prints the direct URL to the uploaded shell.

âœ… Successful Exploit Output

âš ï¸ Disclaimer

This project is for educational and authorized penetration testing purposes only.
Any misuse of this tool is not the responsibility of the author.

æ¼æ´æè¿°ï¼š WordPressçš„Nasa Coreæ’ä»¶ï¼ˆç‰ˆæœ¬6.3.2åŠä»¥ä¸‹ï¼‰å­˜åœ¨ä¸€ä¸ªæœ¬åœ°æ–‡ä»¶åŒ…å«æ¼æ´ï¼ˆCVE-2025-39507ï¼‰ã€‚æ”»å‡»è€…å¯ä»¥é€šè¿‡æ“çºµæ–‡ä»¶è¾“å…¥å‚æ•°æ¥è®¿é—®æœåŠ¡å™¨ä¸Šçš„æ•æ„Ÿæ–‡ä»¶ï¼Œä¾‹å¦‚é€šè¿‡æ„é€ ç‰¹å®šçš„URLè·¯å¾„ï¼ˆå¦‚/index.php?file=../../../../etc/passwdï¼‰æ¥å°è¯•è¯»å–ç³»ç»Ÿæ–‡ä»¶ã€‚è¯¥æ¼æ´æºäºæ’ä»¶æœªèƒ½æ­£ç¡®éªŒè¯æ–‡ä»¶è¾“å…¥ï¼Œå¯¼è‡´æ”»å‡»è€…å¯ä»¥æŒ‡å®šä»»æ„è·¯å¾„è¿›è¡Œæ–‡ä»¶åŒ…å«æ“ä½œã€‚

äº§å“å‚å•†ï¼š WordPress

äº§å“åç§°ï¼š Nasa Core Plugin

å½±å“ç‰ˆæœ¬ï¼š <= 6.3.2

æ¥æºï¼š https://github.com/blackgirlinfosec/cve-lfi-lab

ç±»å‹ï¼š CVE-2025:github search

ä»“åº“æ–‡ä»¶

  • README.md

åŸå§‹ä¿¡æ¯

ğŸ§  CVE Lab: Tier 1 SOC Analyst Simulation

CVE-2025-39507 | Local File Inclusion in WordPress Nasa Core Plugin

ğŸ“ Scenario: A Day in the SOC

Itâ€™s a regular Monday. Iâ€™m logged into the SOC dashboard, reviewing alerts like usual. One comes in that catches my eye:

ALERT: Possible Local File Inclusion (LFI) Attempt
IP Address: 203.0.113.44
URL: /index.php?file=../../../../etc/passwd
User Agent: curl/7.81.0

It looks like someone might be trying to access system files by manipulating a URL. My job is to look into it and decide if this needs to be escalated.

ğŸ” Background on the CVE

After some quick research, I found this matches a known vulnerability: CVE-2025-39507. It affects a WordPress plugin called Nasa Core (version 6.3.2 and below). It allows attackers to view sensitive files on the server by changing a file input parameter.

Example:

If the plugin doesnâ€™t validate the file input correctly, itâ€™ll just follow whatever path the attacker gives it.

ğŸ› ï¸ My Tier 1 Investigation

1. Checked the Alert in Sentinel

I didnâ€™t write the detection rule, but I reviewed it to understand what triggered the alert. It looks for things like:

  • URLs with â€œ../â€ (path traversal)
  • Requests to sensitive files like /etc/passwd or /wp-config.php
  • Scripts or tools in the user agent (like curl or Python)

Hereâ€™s a simplified version of the rule:

2. Looked Up the IP Address

I ran a query to see if the IP 203.0.113.44 was trying anything else:

Turns out, it also hit other paths like /admin/, /login.php, and /wp-config.php. That told me this wasnâ€™t just a one-time request â€” it was probably a scanner or someone doing recon.

3. Checked the Timeline

I checked how long the IP had been active in our logs:

It started a few hours ago and was still active recently. So it wasnâ€™t historical noise â€” this was ongoing.

4. Escalated to Tier 2

Hereâ€™s how I documented it for escalation:

â€œPossible LFI scan from IP 203.0.113.44. The request pattern matches CVE-2025-39507. IP accessed 9 unique paths including /etc/passwd and wp-config.php using curl. Behavior suggests automated recon. Recommend Tier 2 review and possible IP block.â€

ğŸ“¸ Screenshots

#DescriptionFile
1CVE Listing (Patchstack)1_cve_selection_listing.png
2Patchstack Overview2_patchstack_cve_overview.png
3VulDB Vector Example3_vuldb_exploit_vector.png
4Azure Kali VM Created4_kali_vm_deployed.png
5VM Running Screenshot5_kali_vm_running_status.png
6SSH Access to Kali6_kali_vm_logged_in.png
7Sentinel KQL Rule Review7_lfi_detection_kql_query.png

All screenshots are located in the /screenshots folder.

ğŸ” Reflection

Some questions I asked myself as I worked through this:

  • What signs in the logs made this alert stand out?
  • How can I tell if this is just a scanner or something more serious?
  • What else might happen if this LFI attack actually succeeded?
  • Whatâ€™s the right balance between alert fatigue and escalation?

ğŸ”œ Whatâ€™s Next â€“ Phase 2

Next, Iâ€™ll run a safe simulation of this attack in a controlled lab environment using a platform like TryHackMe. The goal is to better understand what this type of activity looks like from the attackerâ€™s side â€” and what kind of logs it creates.

âš ï¸ Disclaimer

This lab was done in a safe, ethical environment for training purposes only. No real systems were targeted or harmed. Always follow your organizationâ€™s rules and never test exploits on systems you donâ€™t own or have permission to test.
